img.caption: Small format, 1/3 A4, portrait. Free, bi-monthly, bilingual, no event description.
Uses 2 different colours on each issue as part of their branding. Simple cover, easily stands out on tables covered in various flyers.
Simple event listings. No artwork photos. Covers all shows for each gallery. No descriptions.
Map area is small: only 2 panels to cover the 40-50 venues. The maps are still usable as all excess/useless details were removed.

Big format, Newspaper style. A3 folded once. Appropriate to the sprawling feel of Yokohama's urban layout. Free, seasonal, bilingual, no event description. CMYK printing, limited to a palette of 8-10 colours. Stylish front page and masthead. Boldness of design is reminiscent of US city maps.
More a showcase of 200 cultural locations in Yokohama than an art event map even though it does include information on a few events.
Vibrant use of colour but the 200 locations referenced on it, the visual hierarchy is lost in too many different font sizes and box shapes.
Unfortunately, the event schedule is a mess
Short A4 folded once. Open like a magazine. Free, monthly, Japanese only. CMYK. Each issue uses a different colours as its main colour on the front page.
More dated design than other maps, closer to a classical music pamphlet for older audiences. More artwork photos than other maps.

Interesting flow of content with 1 interview on 1 page, moving to couple show highlights on the next spread, to heavy listings for a few pages in the middle of the pamphlet, easing out towards the end to just a few other highlighted show and photos.
Each issue include a watercolour map of an art area and a details of the venues in that area. Sharp contrast with other maps.
Tall A3. 3 folds. Free, bi-yearly, bilingual. CMYK with orange, red and grey at the dominant colours.
Edited by the 3 main museums in Roppongi. Valid for 6 months, you can hang on to it longer than other maps.

Map showcases the main venues shows but includes simple details about other venues in the neighborhood. Feels more "wide audience" than other maps. Interesting highlight of pedestrian routes between the venues.

Interesting use of grey shading on part of the side of the map to refocus attention on its center and the main 3 venues. But what's up with those blurry orange drop shadows?! Low contrast on some fonts will be an issue with older audiences. Download it online too: http://www.mori.art.museum/html/eng/atro/img/atro-map.pdf
Very tall, like 2 A3 sheets attached in length. 7 folds Free, related to 1 particular art event, bilingual.

CMYK printing, limited to a palette of 5 colours. Nice paper, mat and rough on 1 side, soft and slightly glossy on the other. Wide area coverage but very usable as all excess/useless details were removed.

Soft colours with some little hand-drawn illustrations (maybe too cute?). Humanist feel. Gill Sans, Axis fonts used. Little pics of the shop/venue fronts, helpful when walking around and trying to find your way.
Great bilingual event schedule.
